metadata.unitName: TEST orange Forces Shape Earth's Surface

questions.question: Which layer of the Earth is the outermost, forming the planet’s surface?

answers.explanation: The crust is the thin, rocky skin on the outside of Earth where landforms, oceans and all life are found.

questions.question: Which layer of the Earth is composed mainly of liquid iron and nickel?

answers.explanation: The intense heat in the outer core keeps its iron–nickel mixture in a molten (liquid) state.

questions.question: List the four main layers of the Earth in order from the outside to the centre.

answers.content: Crust, mantle, outer core, inner core
answers.explanation: Full credit if all four layers are given in the correct order.

questions.question: Despite temperatures similar to the surface of the Sun, Earth’s inner core remains solid because:

answers.content: It is made entirely of rock.
Immense pressure at Earth’s centre keeps the iron–nickel alloy in a solid state.
answers.explanation: The crushing pressure outweighs the effect of high temperature, preventing the metal from melting.

answers.content: There is no heat in the inner core.
It contains large amounts of water.

questions.question: Draw a cross-section diagram of the Earth showing its four main layers. Label each layer and use colour coding or shading to indicate relative thickness. Include one brief annotation for each layer describing its state (solid or liquid) and approximate temperature range.

answers.explanation:
Award up to 6 marks:
• Correctly shows all four layers in the right order (2 marks)
• Each layer clearly labelled (1 mark)
• Appropriate use of colour/shading to show relative thickness (1 mark)
• Accurate annotations about state and temperature (up to 2 marks)

questions.question: Explain how slow-moving convection currents in the mantle can affect features on Earth’s surface.

answers.content: Convection currents in the semi-solid mantle move tectonic plates, causing phenomena such as volcanic eruptions, mountain building and earthquakes at plate boundaries.
answers.explanation:
Award full marks for linking mantle movement to tectonic plate motion and at least one surface effect (e.g.
volcanoes, earthquakes, mountain formation).

questions.question: What is the main cause of most earthquakes on Earth?

answers.content: The sudden movement of tectonic plates along faults
answers.explanation: Stress builds up where plates meet; when it is suddenly released, the plates jolt and the ground shakes.

answers.content: Gradual sinking of the continents into the mantle
Changes in the Moon’s gravitational pull

questions.question: In the Mars-bar model used in class, the solid chocolate layer on top best represented which part of Earth?

answers.explanation: The thin, brittle chocolate coating models the rigid crust that breaks during an earthquake.

questions.question: Which causal connective was practised in the lesson to link the earthquake (cause) with its effects?

answers.explanation: Example: The earthquake struck, so the land rose up.

questions.question: After the 2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake in Japan, which of the following landscape changes was reported?

answers.content: Sections of coastline were uplifted above sea level
answers.explanation: The land around the peninsula was pushed upward, changing the shoreline.

answers.content: A new volcano formed in the centre of the peninsula
Large sand dunes migrated inland due to wind

questions.question: Define a tsunami and explain how it can be triggered by an under-sea earthquake.

answers.content: A tsunami is a series of large, powerful ocean waves produced when a sudden movement of the sea floor—often caused by an under-sea earthquake—displaces a huge volume of water. The shock lifts or drops the water column, generating waves that travel rapidly across the ocean.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram showing two tectonic plates colliding at a fault. Include arrows to show the direction of movement and label the epicentre where the earthquake energy is released.

answers.content: Student supplies labelled diagram displaying: two opposing arrows for plate motion, fault line, epicentre star, crust and mantle labels.

questions.question: What is the name of molten rock while it is still beneath Earth’s surface?

answers.explanation: Molten rock stored underground is called magma. It is only called lava once it erupts onto the surface.
Lava is the name for molten rock after it reaches Earth’s surface.
Ash is the fine rock powder expelled during some eruptions, not molten rock.
Tephra describes the solid material thrown out of a volcano during an eruption.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST describes an immediate (primary) change to the landscape caused by a volcanic eruption?

answers.content: Formation of new fertile soil over centuries
answers.explanation: Fertile soil is a longer-term effect that develops after the ash and lava have weathered.

answers.content: Creation of new land as lava cools and solidifies
answers.explanation: When lava flows and cools, it instantly solidifies into new rock, extending the land surface.
Individual volcanic eruptions do not measurably raise global sea levels.
Finding artefacts is an indirect, historical effect observed long after the eruption.

questions.question: During the lesson model, what household substance represented the gas pressure that drives a real eruption?

answers.explanation: Vinegar represented the acidic fluid reacting with baking soda, not the trapped gas.
The fizzing CO₂ gas produced by the baking-soda/vinegar reaction modelled the pressurised gases inside a volcano.
The clay formed the cone of the volcano, not the gas.
Sand formed the surrounding landscape in the model.

questions.question: Explain one positive and one negative knock-on effect a volcanic eruption can have on humans or ecosystems.

answers.content: Positive: Newly formed volcanic soils become very fertile, improving farming. Negative: Ash clouds can collapse buildings and make breathing difficult.
answers.explanation: Any answer that clearly states a realistic benefit (e.g., fertile soils, new land) AND a realistic hazard (e.g., ash fall, lava destroying homes) should be accepted.

questions.question: Mount Vesuvius buried Pompeii in AD 79. Describe how the volcanic ash helped archaeologists learn about daily life in ancient Rome.

answers.content: The thick ash quickly covered houses, objects and people, preserving them in their exact positions. This acted like a time capsule, so archaeologists could study intact buildings, food, tools and artworks to understand Roman diets, jobs and leisure activities.
answers.explanation: Responses should mention rapid burial/preservation by ash and that this protected artefacts or bodies, providing detailed evidence of Roman life.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram that shows: 1) a volcano before eruption, 2) the same landscape immediately after eruption, and 3) one knock-on effect. Use arrows and causal connectives (e.g., ‘because’, ‘therefore’) to link each stage.

answers.content: Student drawings will vary. A complete answer should include two labelled sketches (before/after), an additional label or small sketch showing the knock-on effect (e.g., new fertile soil, blocked river), and at least one causal connective explaining the sequence.

questions.question: What is the name of the process that breaks rocks down into smaller pieces while they remain in the same place?

answers.explanation: Weathering is the breaking down of rocks in-situ.
Erosion moves already-weathered material.
Deposition is the laying down of eroded material.
Cementation is the binding of sediments into rock.

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT named as an agent of weathering in this lesson?

answers.explanation: Electricity is not discussed as a natural agent of weathering.

questions.question: Why do rocks in a fast-flowing river often become smooth and rounded over time?

answers.content: They melt due to the high temperature of the water.
They are repeatedly struck by sand and other particles carried by the moving water.
answers.explanation: Impacts with abrasive particles chip away rough edges, gradually smoothing the rock.

answers.content: The water chemically changes them into soil instantly.

questions.question: Give TWO examples of causal connectives (linking words) that you could use when explaining how wind weathers rocks.
Describe in one or two sentences how plants can break apart rocks.

answers.content: Plant roots grow into tiny cracks in rocks. As the roots thicken they exert pressure that widens the cracks and eventually splits the rock.
answers.explanation: Roots act like wedges that force cracks to open.

questions.question: In the sugar-cube investigation, what role did SHAKING the jar play?

answers.content: It represented wind or water repeatedly knocking rocks together in nature.
It changed the chemical composition of the cubes.

questions.question: Which sentence is the BEST topic sentence for a paragraph about wind weathering rocks?

answers.content: Wind can cause rocks to become weathered over long periods of time.
Sand is sometimes blown around in deserts.
Sharp rocks can turn into smoother rocks.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple flow chart that shows the seven steps of the sugar-cube weathering investigation carried out in class.

answers.content: Student drawing includes each of the seven numbered steps with appropriate labels (place, draw, place in jar, predict, shake, observe, repeat).

questions.question: Which scientific process moves rock, soil and sand from one place to another?

answers.explanation: Weathering breaks rocks apart but does not move them.
Erosion is the movement of weathered material to a new location.
Deposition is the dropping or settling of eroded material.
Condensation is a change of state in the water cycle, not a geological process.

questions.question: In the tray investigation, what single variable was changed to ensure a fair test?

answers.content: The amount of water poured into each tray
answers.explanation: The same amount of water was poured into each tray.
Only the slope (flat, gentle, steep) was changed between trials.
The same damp sand was used in every tray.

answers.content: The length of the river drawn in the sand
answers.explanation: The river length remained the same.

questions.question: Why does a steeper slope usually cause more erosion by water?

answers.content: Water evaporates faster on steep slopes.
answers.explanation: Evaporation is not the main factor here.

answers.content: Water flows more slowly, giving it more time to pick up sediment.
answers.explanation: Water actually flows faster on a steeper slope.

answers.content: Faster-moving water has more force to carry sediment away.
answers.explanation: Greater speed means greater kinetic energy and erosive force.

answers.content: Gravity is weaker on steeper slopes.
answers.explanation: Gravity is constant; slope changes how gravity accelerates water, not its strength.

questions.question: Select TWO natural forces described in the lesson that can cause erosion.

answers.explanation: Wind can lift and transport particles, especially in dry areas.
The magnetic field does not move rock, soil or sand.
Rivers, rain and waves all erode rock and soil.
Sunlight provides heat but does not directly move sediment.

questions.question: In Aboriginal Dreaming stories, landforms are often explained as being created by:

answers.explanation: Mechanical weathering is the scientific explanation.

answers.content: Supernatural beings such as Super Snake
answers.explanation: Dreaming stories attribute landform creation to ancestral beings.
Plate tectonics is a modern scientific theory, not part of Dreaming stories.
This is not the focus of Dreaming stories.

questions.question: Define erosion in one clear sentence.

answers.content: Erosion is the process that moves weathered rock, soil and sand from one location to another by natural forces such as water, wind or ice.

questions.question: Describe one real-world problem caused by water erosion and suggest a practical solution.

answers.content: Riverbank collapse can threaten houses built close to the water; planting deep-rooted vegetation and installing rock barriers can reduce the speed of the water and stabilise the banks.

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram that shows how water flowing down a steep slope erodes and carries sand to the bottom of the slope. Include arrows to show the direction of water flow and where sediment is deposited.

answers.content: Student diagram should include: a slanted surface, arrows pointing downward with the word 'water', broken-away sand particles, and a labelled 'deposition area' or 'sediment pile' at the bottom.
answers.explanation: Marks awarded for correctly representing flow direction, erosion source area, and deposition zone.
